Based on the user's preference cues, I would recommend the movie "Pushing Tin". This is a drama film that tells the story of two air traffic controllers: one cocky and determined while the other is restrained and laidback, which inevitably affects their lives.

The lead actors in this movie are Matt Ross and Mike O'Malley. These actors bring a great deal of energy and enthusiasm to their roles, making them both compelling to watch and also providing a strong foundation upon which the rest of the story can be built.
As for the other movie options mentioned by the user, I would recommend against those movies. This is because those movies are not in the same genre as "Pushing Tin", which makes it more difficult for those movies to stand out among all of the other movie options that could potentially be recommended instead.

Based on your preferences, I would recommend "Kundun" by Tenzin Thuthob Tsarong.

This is an animated film that tells the story of the fourteenth Dalai Lama and his journey in Tibet over many decades. The animation style is traditional Tibetan art, with bright colors and intricate patterns. Overall, "Kundun" is a beautiful and inspiring film that offers a unique perspective on history, culture, and spirituality.

- Title: Taken (2008)) | Plot: Six friends come together to play "The Game" as a celebration of Nick's birthday. After a few rounds of they get separated while following a black van. Three stop in an alley so that Nick can relieve. His friends are forced into the lost black van by two druges. The other car of friends are informed by the kidnappers that if they want to see them again they have to do exactly what they say. It is revealed that the kidnappers are a modern day Jack the Ripper duo, stalking the streets, picking up prostitutes whom they murder and mutilate. These killer/kidnappers alarmed for being followed, frame these guys. It is the mission of the remaining friends to dispose of the body to retrieve their friends.
